body_text:
This fixes two problems I found while working on #391:


The add-on attempts to clone addon objects into the sandbox, which causes problems. Also, the addon objects don't have filename info like navigator.plugins does. My solution was to just use an object derived from the addon object, and remove the filename property, since we're not really using it anyway.
I ran into a lot of issues trying to write an add-on test for this, mainly trying to mock the list of installed plugins. I opted to leave a test out for now, but future attempts to improve the add-on test coverage should address this.


The Heartbeat event emitter involves some hairy cloning and unwrapping, mainly due to it being in the sandbox and taking the driver as an argument, but being constructed by code outside the sandbox. To simplify this, I moved it out of the sandbox and removed the driver dependency, since it was only using it to log anyway.
From what I read on the original review for the add-on, having the emitter outside the sandbox was mainly a problem due to it having references to other things, but this version is self-contained. I might be wrong on that though.
This doesn't really change any behavior, so existing test coverage should be fine here.


r? @mythmon for everything, @gijsk for the add-on bits.

This fixes two problems I found while working on #391:

- The add-on attempts to clone addon objects into the sandbox, which causes problems. Also, the addon objects don't have filename info like `navigator.plugins` does. My solution was to just use an object derived from the addon object, and remove the filename property, since we're not really using it anyway.

  I ran into a lot of issues trying to write an add-on test for this, mainly trying to mock the list of installed plugins. I opted to leave a test out for now, but future attempts to improve the add-on test coverage should address this.
- The Heartbeat event emitter involves some hairy cloning and unwrapping, mainly due to it being in the sandbox and taking the driver as an argument, but being constructed by code outside the sandbox. To simplify this, I moved it out of the sandbox and removed the driver dependency, since it was only using it to log anyway. 

  From what I read on the original review for the add-on, having the emitter outside the sandbox was mainly a problem due to it having references to other things, but this version is self-contained. I might be wrong on that though. 

  This doesn't really change any behavior, so existing test coverage should be fine here.
